description:
A deep space mission to study an imploding star has met disaster and now the science team and ship's crew face the threat of a forming blackhole. 1 - 6 players can choose to play as either a competitive scientists trying to claim the new discoveries for yourself or as cooperative crew members struggling to survive together. Or you can try to survive alone in solitaire play. Begin your journey trapped in the gravity pull of the vortex. Once free you must reach the rescue ship before becoming permanently trapped in vortex. Game features randomly assigned characters, each with a unique ability, and a dwindling oxygen supply for an added level of difficulty. Players decide the overall difficulty level of the game; from Novice to Madness.

—description from the designer

Family is the most important treasure of all — for now!

You and your cousins may not like each other very much, but you all love your Aunt Agatha — and her vast collection of treasures from around the world! In the fast and frenzied card game Aunt Agatha's Attic, you must race against the clock to bargain with your cousins for the best of Agatha's collection, simultaneously trading glowing emeralds, bone-handled daggers, and even selfless hugs before time runs out. Can you work together to show your aunt just how important family is, all while keeping the best stuff for yourself?

—description from the publisher

Game 1 (Middle Europe)
Each player gest a flight plan card and has to get his plane from indivated starting point to destination point. Movement is determined with two dice.  Between some cities a unlucky number is indicated in the game board. If a player rolls this number with one of his dice while passing this point, he has to undertake an emergency landing and is eliminated from the game.
The first player to arrive at his destination wins the game.

Game 2 (World)
Each player hast to follow 1 of 6 flight plans, determined by the roll of a die. Movement is determined by two dice. If one die shows the number of ones flight plan, the plane is moved according to the second die. If a plane gets on a black dot, it iss lost and the player is eliminated from the game. The first player to arrive at his destination wins the game.

—user summary

Find out how agile you are with Hasbro's Jenga Mini Game

The aim of this exciting game is to test your skill! Take turns taking a block carefully from the tower and placing it on top. But watch out that the tower does not fall over! The longer you spend, the greater the challenge becomes. Who drops the tower and who wins?

—description from the publisher

This is a strategy game about strategy. Trade Secret will challenge your foresight, decision-making, and competitive spirit. It is designed for the seasoned game-lover, continuously learning leader, and business student alike. There is more than one way to learn something by playing this game. All of the strategies in this game are real and promote best practices in Organization Development. Read each strategy description as you introduce new strategies to the game.

Imagine you are the CEO of your new start-up, a strategy guru, ready create the direction for your organization. Your industry is complex and changing. Just last year, the biggest player in the industry unexpectedly collapsed. The first order of business is to gain awareness about your Management, Environment, Communications, Innovation, and Culture. These are five of the most important influences on strategy.

The game itself mirrors a common strategic planning exercise in the business world: the SWOT Analysis. SWOT stands for Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats and the exercise is designed to increase your awareness of your internal and external environment. A good SWOT Analysis then takes the following critical step. You must take that newfound awareness and implement useful strategies for your organization.

But beware, no competitive advantage lasts forever—Except the ability to adapt. Welcome to the world of business psychology and strategic planning.

May the best strategies win!

—description from the designer

Gekitai™ (Repel or Push Away) is a 3-in-a-row game played on a 6x6 grid. Each player has eight colored markers and takes turns placing them anywhere on any open space on the board. When placed, a marker pushes all adjacent pieces outwards one space if there is an open space for it to move to (or off the board). Pieces shoved off the board are returned to the player.

If there is not an open space on the opposite side of the pushed piece, it does not push (a newly played piece cannot push two or more other lined-up pieces).

The first player to either line up three of their color in a row at the end of their turn (after pushing) OR have all eight of their markers on the board (also after pushing) wins.

—description from the designer

The game is provided as an 11" x 17" magazine centerfold.  All instructions and the playing board are provided on the centerfold; a required six-sided die is not included.  Players form two opposing teams with at least two players per team recommended.  The two teams assume the function of the Biblical wise men, traveling from their home to Bethlehem and gathering gifts along the way.

Play alternates between the teams, with each rolling and moving the rolled number of squares.  Squares have game instructions for completion.  Many squares incorporate 6 separate actions, one of which is randomly selected by die roll.  Most game instructions direct some type of trivia exercise, based in Biblical or Christian knowledge of the birth of Jesus Christ and, especially, the visiting wise men.  Successful completion of the trivia activity yields a gift for the team.

The first team to acquire all the needed gifts and then complete the journey to Bethlehem wins the game.

The game is published in the New Era magazine, a publication of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, primarily directed at youth ages 12 to about 18.  Print and PDF copies are available.

—user summary

SQUILLO CITY (CALL GIRL CITY)
ITALY’S BEST SELLING SATYRICAL CARD GAME IS BACK WITH EVEN MORE CRUELTY AND EVEN LESS POLITICAL CORRECTNESS!

The game is set in the city of Milangeles where sex and cultural stereotypes serve as a backdrop for an all-out war amongst the city’s prostitute factions - Russians, Asians, Africans, Americans and Latinas. Pick your favorite and battle it out across town as you engage in shady business, sell yourself on the streets, or off your competitors.

How to play:
Each player’s turn is very quick and composed of two main phases: 
Movement (Mandatory) and Action (Optional)
Movement Phase: 
You must move your character to any new location along the line you’re currently on. The new location may not be occupied by another player.  
Action:
You may take a single action chosen from those on the new location you’re occupying. Alternatively, you may use any action ability present on one of your call girls’ cards as long as its symbol matches the one on the currently occupied location. 
The effects of each action are found on the game board or on the call girl cards. 
After you have taken your action, and if you do not wish to play cards from your hand, you may end your turn and the player on your left will be the next active player.

During your turn you may play as many cards as you like from your hand, as long as their symbols match those on the currently occupied location.

Winning the Game:
The game ends immediately when the last card from the Black Market is purchased or when the last Coin is drawn from the Coin Pool. The player with the most Coins is declared the winner. In case of a draw, the player with the most Call Girls wins - should this also result in a draw, the victory is shared amongst the winning players.

Discover the anniversary edition of the classic Color Addict game!

Even more color cards, red glasses to annoy your opponents ...

Get rid of your cards as quickly as possible by superimposing the words, the colors, the two or the opposite ...

Not to mention the beautiful red glasses, which will change your vision of life (and cards), but especially make you look a bit ridiculous (to distract your opponents ...)!

If you already own the classic version of Color Addict, you can combine the games to play even longer and / or with even more players!

—description from the publisher (translated)

Découvrez l'édition anniversaire du classique Color Addict !

Encore plus de cartes couleurs, des lunettes rouges pour embêter vos adversaires…

Débarrassez-vous de vos cartes le plus vite possible en superposant les mots, les couleurs, les deux ou l’inverse…

Sans oublier les superbes lunettes rouges, qui vont changer votre vision de la vie (et des cartes), mais surtout vous donner un air un peu ridicule (pour déconcentrer vos adversaires...)!

Si vous possédez déjà la version classique de Color Addict, vous pouvez combiner les jeux pour jouer encore plus longtemps et/ou avec encore plus de joueurs!

—description from the publisher

In Distrito 6, each player represents a construction company building the 6th District of Dadópolis, following the district planning, earning points during the game; fulfilling secret goals, which are revealed and scored at the end of the game; and having majority on each floor, earning points at the end of the game.

The game lasts four rounds, divided into four phases each: rolling, players roll all their free dice; allocation, players gain benefits from place their dice into spots on the board; construction, players earn point by constructing dice into the district; and cleaning, players prepare for the next round.

—description from the publisher

AlphaBet is a fun and competitive word creation game. Conceptualised by a copywriter, a designer and an innovator in London - we are the Alpha Pack.

How to play?
Choose your challenge by picking a game Settings Card. This will decide how many words of how many letters you need to create.

Roll the dice and move around the board to collect letters from the library.

When landing on a green letter collect an Alpha card, and a Bet card when landing on a red letter. Each card comes with exciting challenges like:
Rolling the dice in win-or-lose competitions 
Swapping, winning or losing letters 
Exchanging letters with the library and the archive.

Win the game by completing the set word challenge and shout ‘AlphaBet!’.

An AlphaBet game lasts on average 30 minutes and it can be played by 2 to 8 players.

If you enjoy Monopoly and Scrabble, we think this game will be perfect for you.

—description from the designer

This is a game where you can exchange penguin chicks and find out what is the biggest creche.
Each player has three moves.
In those three exchanges, you need to memorize the numbers that have been moved, guess the numbers that are not visible, and do all the handmade things you need to win at the same time.

It is a game that is chewy even in the lightness of a small component packed with several game elements.

This is a fantasy RPG quiz game where prior experience can be used to achieve victory.

The bard (the player who questions) will get points if the audience (the responding player) is correct. However zero points if everyone is correct. In addition, if everyone is wrong, you will be penalized with a negative point.

A card game inspired by a detective drama of the Showa era.

The player becomes one of the "five unique detectives" and investigates the case by allocating 24 hours each. Five cases are set at the same time, and a five-row, plot-type auction is held. Scores will be given to the 1st and 2nd place "in the time allotted" for each case. Do this for 3 hands.

Detectives work together to investigate the case, but often go to stand, play to seek credit, or settle with the culprit. As a result, you may get deeply involved in the incident and get seriously injured or you may be killed!ã€€Moreover, even if you get a line of duty, the game is not over, and if you can get a line of duty at a good show, you can earn a high score. Produce your own line of duty scene well and decide "What's this !!!!"

The basis of the game is a "5-row, plot-type auction".ã€€A total of 24 common cards will be given to the player as a hand, and one card will be placed in each of the five cases, for a total of five cards. After placing, reveal the cards, and after seeing the result, arrange the remaining 5 sheets in the same way and judge by the total value. Therefore, it is important to avoid competition as much as possible and get more cases efficiently, because it is possible to guess to some extent who wants which case with the first placement.

Then, shouldn't it be better to hide the information by arranging as few numbers as possible for the first placement? Of course, that's one strategy. However, if the numbers are the same, there is a rule that the one with the larger number placed on the first sheet wins, so it is not always advantageous to arrange the smaller numbers.ã€€In addition, each person has a ticket called hero time, and you can win regardless of the number unless the heroes spend time fighting with each other. Where to use this hero time is also important.

Date Dragons, Without Getting Burned!

Are you a dragon looking for companionship? 
Or just the adventurous type, looking to join the exciting dragon dating scene? Cindr is a ‘push your luck’ dice and card game that allows players to set up a dating profile and then thumb through potential matches, seeing if a given dragon sounds compatible.

If so, Meet Up and say hello – and if that goes well, push your luck, and take the Next Step. You never know, before the date is over you may just take things to the Next Level! The better the dates go, the more Love points you earn – but watch out, just 3 Flames will leave you burned, scoreless and searching for love all over again. Will you be the first of your friends to find love and fulfillment?


     A 30-minute, push your luck dice game for 1-5 players, where the more compatible you are, the better the odds get of not getting burned.



     A fun, light-hearted send-up of dating apps like Tinder, with tarot-sized cards as the app deck and date locations with special bonuses provided by the “Whelp” app deck.


—description from the publisher

1958 NT
Reckless children enter a New England old manor house, looking for their friend Damien who has been missing for several days..

Damien is the prequel to Cavendish.

Battle for Treasure on the High Seas!

The Risk Jr. board game features easy-to-get gameplay, an engaging pirate theme, and bold, colorful artwork. Kids move their boat token around the game board in search of buried treasure as they battle for control of the islands, aiming to collect the most loot to win. The game requires no reading, is quick to set up, and can be played in less than 30 minutes. Engage family members ages 5 and up with this junior edition of the classic strategic combat game.

INTRO TO THE CLASSIC RISK GAME: The Risk Junior board game is a great way to introduce kids to the strategy gameplay of the classic Risk game. The game is for kids ages 5 and up; for 2 to 4 players
PIRATE THEME: The Risk Junior game's pirate theme has kids moving their pirate ship tokens around the board, competing for treasure and control of the islands
LAUNCH THE DICE: Place, press, launch! To battle another player to claim an island and its treasure, players put a die in their pirate ship, press the lever, and launch it to discover the next move
GAME OF STRATEGIC CONQUEST: Move pirates on to islands, defend territories, and control of treasures. The player with the most treasure and islands at the end of the game wins
MY FIRST RISK GAME: The Risk Jr. game is a great way to introduce kids to the classic strategy board game.

My City is a competitive legacy game in which you develop a city on your own playing board through the ages.

The game consists of 24 episodes, beginning with the development of a city in its early preindustrial stages and progressing through industrialization. During each game, players customize their experience by adding elements to their personal boards and adding cards to the game. Players' choices and action made during one session of gameplay carry over into the next session, creating a personalized gaming experience.

For players who do not want to experience My City as a legacy game, a double-sided game board offers an alternate set-up for repeatable play (some elements from the legacy experience are needed for the repeatable play game, players can unlock these elements by playing through the first 4 episodes).

Speed is of the essence in the co-operative game Dodo as the bird has laid its egg on the highest mountain peak, but then unobservantly let it fall out of the nest and towards the cliff...

By using teamwork, you can bring the rolling egg safely to the foot of the mountain! Quickly roll the building material you need, collect hammers and nails, and attach bridges to the sides of the mountain. If you manage to steer the egg safely into the lifeboat, you've won together.

Bones & Banners is a fantasy field battle game played with dice and cards. Each player commands their own army deck of unit cards that are used to defend allied lands and conquer enemy lands to be victorious. Players can also hire advisors and construct practical buildings to better their odds in winning the game.

—description from the designer

The world of stars that once looked up from the ground.
With the rapid development of space technology, the human race that finally enabled interstellar navigation
At last, we will start exploring unknown planets.

Waiting there is a brilliant glory or an unexpected ruin.
The greatest romance of mankind opens!

Run your very own paper company branch, while navigating the shifting economy, hiring employees, and maintaining your branch's morale.

In Paper Company, the economy is determined for all players based on a single die roll each round. The higher the roll is, the better the economy and the stronger each players' actions will perform that round. Once the economy is determined, all players choose 1 of 5 actions based on the roll:

     Accounting: To gain money
     Purchasing: To buy paper
     Sales: To sell paper
     Human Resources: To increase morale
     Recruiting: To hire or fire employees


By acquiring employees you can increase the benefits for specific actions, gain benefits when other players perform matching actions, and obtain abilities unique to that employee. However, be cautious who you hire, as employees have minds of their own always triggering their abilities, whether you want them to or not.  You must also be wary of how you treat your employees, as each branch has unique benefits, or detriments, based on how your employees feel about your management style.

With 5 unique branches and 40 unique employees, every game plays out differently. How will you manage your unique branch? Will you focus on one action, allowing other players to take advantage of your repetition? Will you get and keep morale high to reap the benefits of happy, productive employees, or try to make money quickly and work around the consequences? Will you focus on recruiting and fill your office with as many employees as you can, or will you try to avoid employees altogether and run the office by yourself?

—description from the designer

In the city of Kokomo, the ruffian know as “The Jazz Man” has opened up a shady casino called The House Of Jive. The residential toons of Kokomo aren’t too happy about this and try to get the casino shut down. They however do not succeed as The Jazz Man is protected with the magic of “The Great Kokkino” and the might and insanity of “Jack De Lune”. Our heroes “Vega O’ Dar”, “Darla Dwolf”, and “Coyote Pete” have been alerted by The Jazz Man’s actions and are teaming up with YOU to stop him and get his casino shut down! With the magic of The Great Kokkino, he is holding all of these other toon’s against their will and are being forced to fight and protect the casino. Will you defeat The Jazz Man? Or will you succumb to his game?

—description from the designer

ZENã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ« ã‚½ãƒ­ (ZEN Tiles Solo) is a solitaire board game that challenges you to look at yourself objectively while placing emotion tiles on a 24-hour timeline.

To win, you need to find a spot to place twenty different emotion tiles above these time boards, so think carefully about "your yesterday". You might have become happy about yourself — "I had a positive thoughts!" — or were perhaps surprised: "I didn't realize that I have negative feelings every time when I see this person."

"Knowing yourself" is one of the most important processes to find a way to make our life better, and it is ZEN. Giving five minutes each day to yourself to play this game alone in a quiet place and listen to your soul could be good meditation for the people who feel tired every day.

ZEN Tile Solo is a game through which you can learn your hidden emotions and organize them to make your life calmer and better.
publisher's summary

ZENã‚¿ã‚¤ãƒ« ã‚½ãƒ­ (Zen Tiles Solo) published in 2019, has wooden components in a small, silver foil stamped box. It is a one player game. There are 20 Emotion Tiles, a time track and 1 Elegant Stone. The rules are in English and Japanese, with both languages shown on the Emotion Tiles. ZenTiles are from Fukui Prefecture, where the Eiheiji Temple, also known as the birthplace of Zen, is located.
user summary

GAME SYSTEM

    
    
         This entry is to allow for discussion/rating of the game system as a whole. It is not for a specific product or release. Versions will appear on the individual item pages.

    



 Unmatched is a highly asymmetrical miniature fighting game for two or four players. Each hero is represented by a unique deck designed to evoke their style and legend. Tactical movement and no-luck combat resolution create a unique play experience that rewards expertise, but just when you've mastered one set, new heroes arrive to provide all new match-ups.

Combat is resolved quickly by comparing attack and defense cards. However, each card's unique effects and a simple but deep timing system lead to interesting decisions each time. The game also features an updated version of the line-of-sight system from Tannhäuser for ranged attacks and area effects.

—description from the publisher

Deckscape Crew vs Crew: Pirates' Island is part of a series of games inspired by real escape rooms in which a group of people is "trapped" inside a room full of puzzles and odd items. The goal of the game is to solve puzzles, understand the plot of the story, and make intelligent use of the items provided in order to exit from the room as quickly as possible.

Deckscape Crew vs Crew: Pirates' Island differs from other Deckscape titles by adding a competitive element to the game! Players split into two teams and try to correctly solve the puzzles before the other team does. This chapter also features puzzle-based mini-games specially designed for a competitive experience!

In Dungeon Mayhem: Monster Madness, you play as one of six epic D&D monsters, each with their own way to charm, crush, disintegrate, and devour their foes.

Store all your Dungeon Mayhem cards in this monster-sized box, then select your favorite character and pit it against any other deck in the game line. Plus, you can enjoy bringing more adventurers into the fold with new rules to allow for mayhem with up to six players at once!

A kingdom stands on the brink of destruction, as the vast realm called the Shadow Deep slowly swallows everything in its path. As the army fights to contain the tide of evil creatures teeming up out of the black clouds, the kingdom’s best soldiers, the rangers, must venture down into the shadows to gather information, rescue prisoners, and ambush enemy supply lines. It is a desperate fight against overwhelming odds, but every little victory brings another day of hope.

Rangers of Shadow Deep is a solo and co-operative tabletop miniatures game, in which players create their ranger, gather companions, and play through a series of missions in their fight to hold back the darkness. If their rangers survive, they will grow in power and ability, and be sent on more difficult, dangerous and intricate assignments.

So, what is going to make this ‘Deluxe’, I hear you ask? Well, to start off, it’s getting top-notch production – traditional printing and binding, with a faux leather cover heat stamped with the artwork and text, and high-quality paper stock. The layout is being completely reworked, and the book will feature a dozen pieces of new artwork by Barrett Stanley. Additionally, I’m taking the chance to incorporate the character building elements (most notably the spells) from Temple of Madness into the main rulebook, so that all of the character building will be in one place. I am also updating or modifying a few of the rules that I, and others, have been playtesting. Finally, I have introduced a ‘challenge level’ for each of the scenarios in the book, which increases the difficulty of each scenario. This is for those that were finding the scenarios too easy for 3 or 4 players, for those who just like their games tougher, or for those who might want to play the scenarios again with higher-level rangers.

—description by the publisher

Canopy is a game in which two players compete to grow the most bountiful rainforest. The jungle ecosystem is full of symbiosis and mutualism, and players must grow tall trees and lush jungle plants to attract the most diverse wildlife. By carefully selecting what grows in your forest, you can create the ideal balance of flora and fauna and develop a thriving rainforest.

In the game, players take turns selecting new cards for their forest from three growth piles. Each time you look at a pile, you may select it and add those cards to your rainforest tableau, or return the pile face down, adding one additional card to it. As the piles grow, you must search for the plants and animals that will benefit your forest the most — but choose carefully as the jungle also contains dangers in the form or fire, disease, and drought.

—description from the publisher

There are options for three and four players, together with a solo game. Also included is a addional deck of season variant cards.

The land you live in has been at war for as long as any of you have been alive.
The Queen has decided to undertake a long and perilous journey to broker an alliance with a distant power.
The Queen has chosen you, and only you, to be her retinue, and accompany her on this journey.
She chose you because she knows that you love her.

For the Queen is a card-based story-building game that you and up to five other players can begin playing in minutes. Choose your queen from among fourteen gorgeously varied illustrations—or start from scratch—and use the prompt cards to collaboratively tell a story of love, betrayal, doubt, and devotion.

—description from the publisher

This game also has an entry on RPGGeek: For the Queen

A Luminous Flame in The Darkness (LFID) is innovative Board Game for sharing and learning. The LFID is Homemade Integrated Design. It is also suitable for a solo game at home.  The player can share and learn about ethic, goodness, moral, and core cultures while they adventure and explore with many experiences on the map of a community. Some happenings tend to be worse. How do they live? How do they make a decision? or How do they take an action?

Each Player can create Core Culture and a story together, including modify rules. In the game, the player may see a picture emerge of inter-relationships with multiple factors that are connected, such as causes that lead to multiple degenerations or the existence of individual forces against outer contexts. Preservation and recovery of life is more difficult than destruction. Creativity, life, people and the maintenance are essential for the existence of a core culture. The environment is not for the individual to exploit, but for all lives to enjoy.  This game simulates incidents happening in a world of fantasy in which virtue and ethics are crucial to the survival of humanity.  Each player will be able to perceive an overall concept of the core culture which they created together in the game.

    Note : In case of using for eduacional game, an experienced adult or parent is required to teach and guide.


BACKGROUND :
I graduated in Ph.D. of Arts and Culture Research from the Faculty of Fine Arts of Srinakarinwirot University in Bangkok, Thailand. My research of Green Culture for Ethics Through Documentary Films, found out the issues of many problems and wide ranging effects, including the realisation that the relationship between natures and ethics are complementary in both the individual and public contexts. The complimentary nature of living in accordance with an ecological system leads to a balance between the physical and subjective, the concrete and the abstract, human behaviour and the mind which can be seen as the foundation of ethics for peaceful and sustainable mutual living.

A Game Story :
After humanity has destroyed nature and the environment in many areas, some of the areas have  been restored and rejuvenated. Nevertheless, many people turn to violence to hurt and destroy each other for fame and wealth, focusing on dominating the land which causes many problems and adverse living conditions.  People have lost trust for each other : no faithfulness exists. They have lived in unsafe place and lead insecure lives. At the same time that pollution has dominated and deterioration also spreads widely into several areas.  In one remote district, a city that was once full of happiness, many things have began to change. However, the last thing that still keeps faith and hope and that will not be destroyed so easily, the GOODNESS OF PEOPLE

OBJECTIVE
All players help most members in their community to stay away from evil power before most terrible things appear. They try to cultivate goodness and ethics in the land of loss before the darkness comes.  At the end of game, all players consider successful future and present outcomes together.

GENRE
Fantasy game, 
Solo Game,
Co-operative game, 
Strategic game, 
and Educational game

COMPONENTS
1. 16 Miniatures / 16 Character Markers
2. 3 Draw Bags
3. 12 Intelligence Dice
4. 12 Conscience Dice
5. 6 Open-Mind Dice
6. 8 Sincerity Dice

40. 1 Game Board
41. 1 Rule Book

WARNING : This is not a toy. Not for use by children under age of 4 years old.  The game contains small parts that can be swallowed.

—description from the designer

Welcome one and all to Spyfest, the largest super spy convention in the world! You are here to get a precious piece of secret information, but there is a complication: Everyone is wearing a costume, and you don't know who your source is. Find your spy by listening and talking to the visitors, but you have to remember that the interceptors are on site, too, and they might get ahead of you and unveil your spy before you do!

Spyfest — released in Russia under the name Spycon — is a storytelling detective party game in which players split into two teams and take turns being the spy. The goal of the spy is to make their own team guess which costume they are wearing in such a way that the opposing team wouldn't get it. In order to do this, the spy and their team use a special keyword as well as their quick-wittedness, limitless fantasy, subtlety, and impressive talent for mingling.

In Spyfest, the most creative and ingenious team wins, so most importantly — stay on your toes!

—description from the publisher

Konamon! (literally "things made from flour") is a game about sharing a kitchen but competing to get the most points. You'll have to work together with the other staff if you ever want to serve a customer, but if you cooperate you can end up giving the other players points.

Each round a new customer arrives at the restaurant. Then each player chooses an action card and reveals them simultaneously. Actions are taken from the lowest number up; you can prep food in the kitchen, move food from the kitchen to the burners, or serve cooked food to customers. Each action succeeds only if there's space for the food. You get one point for each action you complete, plus bonus points if you fill up a customer's order. This repeats until all the customers are gone.

There's one big wrinkle in the dough though - each round customers get more impatient, and if they get fed up and leave the player currently in first loses points. This means that if you're behind it's in your best interest to antagonize the leader by filling the kitchen with food nobody ordered, serving customers who just arrived first, or other kinds of bad service. But since you might be the leader next turn you'll have to strike a balance.

What will you cook up in Konamon!?

—user summary

In Too Deep is a unique, narrative that thrusts you into the future in a tense, strategic board game for 1-5 players. Draft characters and spend actions to complete objectives and collect sets. What side of the law will you end up on?

In the year 2087, central governments have fallen. What remains are fragmented citystates like New Dawn City, struggling to keep chaos at bay. The sinister Syndicate targets these weakened cities for domination by usurping, organizing, and enhancing the existing criminal elements. In the world of In Too Deep, you are part of a secret agency dedicated to stopping the Syndicate at all costs.

Cybernetic implants give Syndicate operatives a technological advantage, but you have found a way to exploit that power. By infiltrating their cerebral upgrades, you can gain control of these criminals. Going deep undercover into the minds of your targets, you’ll coordinate crimes of escalating seriousness to get your hands on the critical evidence needed to foil the Syndicate’s looming plot.

Each turn, you can hook into a new criminal and manipulate their activities throughout the city, accessing powerful skills and increased stamina as you grow familiar with their minds. Your physical body is in a secret lab far from the actual action, but you are by no means safe. Entering the mind of criminals takes its toll on your morality.

Orchestrate crimes, strive to put the information you gather to the best use, wrestle with dangerously corrupting dilemmas, and try to hold yourself together. It will take everything you’ve got to avoid going In Too Deep.

Catchy! (ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒƒãƒãƒ¼ï¼) is a tug-of-war-like trick-taking game for two players.

In Catchy! you will try to allure Alex, a fickle cat, and have him come into your arms by showing him what he likes. But be careful, as he is so much whimsical that he changes his mind so often; the thing he loved to play with may not be his kind anymore a minute after!


    In this game, Alex is represented in a tile, and it is two-sided; one side is red colored and the other is blue colored.


In Catchy! players play ordinary trick-taking game in which the latter player must follow the suit, if possible. Two players take turn to play one card for one trick, and if both two players play “odd” numbers, Alex flips to the other side; red side being up, it flips to the blue, and vice versa.
Then, he moves towards one of the players by one step according to the rule following: if its red side is up, he moves to the player who took the trick, and if its blue side is up, he moves to the other, s/he who did not take the trick.
After players’ hands have been exhausted, or Alex has moved into one players field, arms, one round ends and the player who has Alex closer to him/her scores points.
Rounds are played on and on until one player gains 7 points, then s/he who has 7 points wins the game.

As you may see, in this game, even in one round, you sometimes have to become eager to take tricks and sometimes you do not. This tricky twist is the core of Catchy!

This game is small (only 17 cards used), but needing its players to think strategically and concentrate on making most of their hand.
This portable game surely takes you to a cute but strategical “catchy” world anytime, anywhere, and anywhere you are with.

—description from the designer
Nice Egg! (ãƒŠã‚¤ã‚¹ã‚¨ãƒƒã‚°ï¼) is a yolk-dropping action game in which players are challenged to drop yolks one by one each round. Can you be a fried egg master?

An antique board game, presumably published between Andrée's first attempt in 1896 and his historic failure in 1897, with the trademark for Luxus Papier Fabrik, Berlin, and a copyright mark, Made in Germany.

A double folding board, approx 23" [58.5cm] square when opened, with a portrait vignette of Andrée, Surcouf, Godard and Strindberg in each corner, each following a route to the pole along numbered places. According to the Instruction sheet, the game should contain :- Plan, 4 balloons, 2 dice, and a number of counters. Box cover is with a portrait vignette of Andrée and an unfortunately chosen picture of three men in a balloon amongst an iceberg laden sea, the drag lines lying in the water.

—user summary

Two teams come face to face to perform the best routine in this synchronized swimming card game!

Memorize your routine, and recreate it all with cards. The team with the highest score after four rounds wins the game.

Every round is in three faces: Rehearsal, Competition, Performance. 
In Rehearsal both teams will lay out a routine with 6 to 11 pose cards and memorize the sequence. Once a team has their routine memorized, they grab the whistle to end this phase for both teams, and cards are flipped face down. 
For the Competition, a duplicate deck is dealt among team members. Players place cards face down below their corresponding rehearsal cards. 
Once both teams are done, each team will Perform, flipping and comparing all their cards. For each matching rehearsal and competition card pose, they score a point. 
Each round increases with one additional routine pose, and a Challenge card adding rules.

—description from the publisher

In Couperation (ã‚¯ãƒ¼ãƒšãƒ¬ã‚¤ã‚·ãƒ§ãƒ³), players try to play cards from their hand to create a card pyramid seven layers high while staying within certain rules for the placement of cards.

Cards in the deck range from 1-50, and the cards numbered 1 and 50 — along with 2-4 other random cards — are placed in the reserve at the top of the playing area before the game begins. Each player receives a hand of three cards.

On a turn, you draw 0-4 cards from the deck depending on which card was played the previous turn. (The first player of the game optionally draws one card.) Then you can play a card face up or face down in the pyramid. Within a row, card values must escalate from left to right; when placing a card on a higher row, that card must be supported by two other cards and the newly placed card's value must be between the values of the two supporting cards. When you place a card face down, you ignore the value restriction.

Alternatively, you can discard two cards to the reserve, then draw a card from the reserve that equals the sum or the difference of these two cards. (You can discard other cards in your hand from the game to raise or lower this sum/difference by 1 for each such card.) You then place this card from the reserve in the tower, either in an empty spot or in place of another card (with you adding this replaced card to your hand).

If you manage to create a card tower seven layers tall (i.e., with 28 cards) and all those cards are face up, then you win.

Once you play a few times, you can add the Finish card (#25) to the game. During set-up, you shuffle this card in the bottom half of the deck. Whoever draws it places this card in front of themselves, then draws a replacement card. The Finish card is part of this player's hand, but doesn't count against their three-card hand limit. The Finish card cannot be played face down, and if it's removed from the tower, it must be placed face up in front of the active player. The Finish card must be the final card played at the top of the tower for players to win.

Memoletras is an evolved memotest.
With 40 letters arranged on the table in a hidden way, each participant must turn 4 in their turn. Each participant receives 2 tokens, each with a 4-letter word.
If he manages to turn the 4 that make up one of the words he touched, he shows it and forms the first word. If it does not form a word, it must remember the letters that appear in its turn and in that of its opponents.

With italic words, you must test your memory.
From 7 years old, between 2 and 5 players.


Memoletras es un memotest evolucionado. 
Con 40 letras dispuestas en la mesa de forma ocultas, cada participante deberá dar vuelta 4 en su turno. Cada participante recibe 2 fichas, cada una con una palabra de 4 letras.
Si logra dar vuelta las 4 que conforman alguna de las palabras que le tocó, la muestra y forma la primera palabra. Sino forma una palabra, deberá recordar las letras que aparezcan en su turno y en el de sus oponentes.

Con palabras en cursiva, deberás poner a prueba tu memoria.
A partir de los 7 años, entre 2 y 5 jugadores.

Euthia: Torment of Resurrection is an open-world sandbox RPG strategy for 1-4 players that can be played competitively, cooperatively, or solo. Choose one of six heroes with different play styles and unique ability trees and embark on a wide range of epic, fantasy adventures through infinitely replayable scenarios. Wander through an expanding open world generated by modular map tiles that will be different every time you play. Discover areas where you can fight monsters, gather resources, trade with merchants, pursue side quests, and confront elemental powers. Your actions grant you reputation and wealth so you can develop your hero by unlocking new abilities and customizing your equipment.

—description from the publisher

Plakks is a fast-paced and exciting wooden football game that's perfect for players of all ages. Made from recyclable materials, this game is not only fun but also environmentally friendly.

Players can customize their players with their favorite teams, creating a unique and personalized experience every time they play. The game features a set of wooden sticks that represent the football players on the field, and players must use their skill and strategy to beat their opponent. The game is played as follows:

•START SHOOTING: After the initial draw, one of the players starts by kicking the ball with his finger to try and score a goal. 
•OPPONENT'S TURN: The opponent kicks from where the ball was left, and so on until one of the two opponents scores a goal.
•GOOOAL: The opponent who has conceded a goal has to remove one of his players and kick off from the point within his penalty area.
•WINNER: Wins the player who has managed to leave the opponent without any players, including the goalkeeper.

With its high-quality components and extensive customization options, Plakks is the perfect game to enjoy the most epic football matches with your friends and family. Whether you are a passionate football fan or just looking for a fun and competitive game, Plakks is sure to provide you with hours of entertainment and excitement.

—description from the publisher

In this alt-sports game, choose your team, pick your starting lineup from the cards, then roll the dice in a series of back-and-forth possessions across a classic American gridiron.  Most points at the end of eight alternating possessions wins the game.  Add in the advanced strategy cards for even more managerial tactical options.

In a crumbling future where concrete and smog cover the country, football remains America’s pastime.

Evolved to satisfy the frenzy of its audience, the game has grown faster, harder, and more brutal.  With precious contracts and salaries on the line,  teams do whatever it takes to bring home the victory.  This is the future.  This... is Fury Football.

Assemble your league and watch as teams square off to be crowned the Fury Football Champion.  Manage a team of your own to see if you can take it to the top.  Play either solo or head-to-head against another player and compete for victory and glory.  The possibilities are endless with Fury Football and your new, unique sports universe.

—description from the publisher

Savage Wilderness - The French and Indian War is our second game simulation of the French and Indian War, the North American theater of The Seven Years’ War fought between the English and French. One of the key aspects of this conflict was control of the two rivers that served as critical trade routes for both nations, the Allegheny and Monongahela.

Designed by Bill Molyneaux, Savage Wilderness provides gamers with a fast-playing, introductory-level wargame covering twelve engagements of this war, including alternate variants for you to explore. Using easy to understand rules, each scenario is designed to be played in about an hour. Special scenario rules expand the experience further, bringing unique flavor and mechanics specific to each engagement while staying historically correct.

Battles included in this game are Grand Pre, Petitcodiac, Fort Bull, Mercer’s Massacre, Fort Oswego, Kittanning, German Flatts, Battle of Fort Ligonier, La Belle Famille, Beauport, Bloody Morning Scout, Bloody Run, Devil’s Hole, and the 30 turn campaign: The Battle of Fort Fredrick.

—description from the publisher

Monomyth, the Hero's journey. A fantastic adventure where a group of adventurers will seek to face fantastic beasts that are recognized as the greatest heroes in history. A deck building game where we will be building our future fighting together (or not) against everything that faces us.

The game consist in players that choose their Champions for a great variety. Each one has it's owns skills an abilities. Each on has a set of initial deck of movements (Protection and attacking).

Minimum 3 players. The Setup is made buy two others decks of cards (enemies and situations/places). On the player turns, 1 Monster card and 1 situation/places card is Show. The cards show the enemies's handicap, the initial deck that this one has, and the situation/place will make a Stronger or a weaker enemy.

The player in the turn decide to offer to others players that someone joins him in this particular adventure sharing the prizes that the enemy offers (Victory points and treasures).

The negotiation begins and only one player could join him. The other one Will act as the Enemy, moving it by him.

The winner will be the player that hits an amount of Victory Points previously defined.

—description from the designer

He who can beat the dangerous monster from the underworld wins the game, but it is not as easy as some can imagine. First, you have to start looking for objects in Schemermeer, objects you'll need to beat the monster. Each turn you roll a die and can either move your pawn or attack a monster. Each monster in schemermeer is guarding an object. Beating the monster (also dice-rolling) grants you the object. When you have found the needed objects, go down to the underworld (game board under the table) and battle much more dangerous monsters to find the potion needed. With the correct objects, the potion and a little bit of luck, you can beat the final boss-monster.

In å‘ªè¡“ãƒˆãƒªãƒƒã‚¯ (Cursed Tricks), players aim to take the most cards over a series of hands.  Each card taken will be worth 1 point; however, when a player wins a trick, the card that won the trick may "curse" them, causing them not to score cards of that color.  If a player takes a curse of a second color, they cannot score points at all, and if a player collects a third curse, the round ends prematurely and the player scores negative points.

Curses may be passed to other players who win a trick of that color with a higher ranked card than the current curse, and curses may be broken by players who follow suit and play the lowest card of that suit to a trick.

The player with the most points after a certain number of rounds wins.
